headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Tamara, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to your
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Tamara, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Rob Csongor, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call on annual and fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 results. With me on the call today from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Karen Burns, Interim Chief Finan
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call on annual and fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 results. 
With me on the call today from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Karen Burns, Interim Chief Financial Officer. After our prepared remarks, we will open up the call to a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] .
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's call is being webcast live on NVIDIA's Investor Relations website and is also being recorded. A replay of the conference call will be available via telephone until February 22, 2012, and the webcast will be available for replay until our conference call to discuss our financial results for our first quarter of fiscal 2013. The content of today's conference call is NVIDIA's property and cannot be reproduced or transcribed without our prior written consent.
During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially. For a discussion of factors that could affect our future financial results and business, please refer to the disclosure in today's earnings release, our Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended October 30, 2011, and the reports we may file from time to time on Form 8-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
All our statements are made as of today, February 15, 2012. Based on information available to us as of today, and except as required by law, we assume no obligation to update any such statements. Unless otherwise noted, all references to market research and market share numbers throughout the call come from Mercury Research or Jon Peddie Research.
During this call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures. You can find a reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures in our financial release, which is posted on our website or in the case of our fiscal year 2013 outlook, the reconciliation is posted on our Investor Relations website.
With that, let's begin. After 5 consecutive quarters of sequential revenue growth, fourth quarter revenue was negatively impacted by the global disk drive shortage, caused by the flooding in Thailand, which upset the mainstream and GPU segment more than anticipated. 
Shipments by some PC OEMs were reduced, and higher disk drive prices constrained the ability of some PC OEMs to include GPU in their systems.
Additionally, the Tegra 2 mobile business declined more rapidly than expected ahead of devices based on the Tegra 3 processor ramping into production in the first quarter of calendar year 2012. 
However, despite tough economic conditions and the exiting of our chipset business, NVIDIA recorded very good results for our full fiscal year 2012.
First, our overall business grew 33%, excluding the chipset business we've been exiting. Discrete GPUs, including GeForce, Quadro and Tesla grew sharply over the year. GPU attach rates remained strong at 53% of consumer PCs and 36% overall, according to Mercury Research data.
Our research and PC gaming market saw games like Battlefield 3 and Modern Warfare 3 record over $1 billion in sales in their first week on the shelves. At the time of the launch of Battlefield 3, over 80% of gamers were below the recommended hardware specification to play the game, driving a significant increase in gamer GPU revenues over the year.
Our Professional Solutions Business had a record revenue year driven by large adoption of the Fermi generation of quarter workstation products, as well as growth in the emerging design economies such as India and China.
Our Tesla products were selected to power the world's fastest supercomputers, including Oak Ridge national laboratories upcoming timing supercomputer. In addition, we made major strides in speeding of GPU computing applications support and code porting through our open FTC and directive initiatives.
And then one of our most important achievements for the year, we established a position in the mobile market. Tegra products captured share in Tier 1 tablets and smartphones. Over the course of the year, Tegra products shipped in 14 phones, 34 tablets and then 18 of the top 20 carriers. We designed and shipped 3 generations of Android devices.
With Tegra 2, we were dispersed to ship dual core mobile processors. And now with Tegra 3, we're the first to ship quad core processors. The Tegra mobile processor has grown into a multi-hundred million dollar business.
Looking ahead, while we anticipate continued negative effects from the hard drive shortage, we believe gaming demand will continue to be robust, driven by the combination of our next-generation Kepler architecture and new hit games, such as Mass Effect 3 and Diablo 3, both highly anticipated PC games coming in early calendar year 2012.
We believe that tax rates will continue to be stable, and that we are well positioned to grow notebook share with significant new notebook wins in the upcoming IV rich design cycle.
We are excited about a number of recent announcements we made in the professional space, which we believe will transform the workstation. 
First, yesterday, we announced that NVIDIA has joined forces with HP to introduce the world's first of all-in-one workstation, the Quadro-based HP Z1 Workstation. The Z1 features a 27-inch display that snaps open like the hood of the car, so users can easily slap out part and make upgrades without any tools required.
This is the first and an entirely new category of professional workstation that we believe will tap market segments or space at the premium and uses are unwilling to compromise performance. 
Second, we announced Maximus, a breakthrough for the workstation industry. Maximus enables for the first time a single workstation to simultaneously handle realtime visualization and compute-intensive simulation, functions which previously required separate steps or separate systems. 
Design and creative professional have long for machine that could perform these functions simultaneously. Maximus includes the combination of Quadro and Tesla, unifying software technology and a rigorous certification process for professional applications. We believe Maximus will redefine the workflow in several segments and that workstations will increasingly shift with multiple GPUs.
Meanwhile, Tesla continued to make headlines in computational science. In addition to a number of new supercomputer deployment announcements, we announced breakthroughs in research. Two of the most important supercomputers in the world were recently announced in Oak Ridge National Labs in the and NCSE's Blue Waters, both Tesla-based. Chinese researchers announced they had achieved a major breakthrough in the race to battle information is that by using NVIDIA Tesla GPUs to create the world's first computer simulation of a whole H1N1 influenza virus at the atomic level.
With Tegra 3, we believe our mobile business is poised for renewed growth. 
In addition to the launch of the world's first quad core tablet, the Asus Transformer Prime, we announced tablets based on Tegra 3 from a number of key OEMs, including Lenovo, GTE, Fujitsu and Acer.
We also announced together with Asus the world's first quad core tablet priced at $249. The Asus 7-inch Memo ME 37 ET. 
Next up, our Tegra 3 phones. We're looking forward to announcing some of the first ones at Mobile World Congress. 
With innovating exciting new tablets at the high end, quad core tablets have lowered price points for consumers, world's first quad core smartphones coming soon and Windows 8 devices later in the year, we remain confident that Tegra 3 will drive a new phase of growth for our mobile business.
With that, let me hand the call over to Karen.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. For the fiscal year 2012, revenue was $4 billion, up 12.8% from the prior year. GAAP net interest income grew 129.5%, resulting in an earnings of $0.94 per diluted share, an increase of 118.6% over the prior fiscal year of $0.43.Non-GAAP ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. For the fiscal year 2012, revenue was $4 billion, up 12.8% from the prior year. GAAP net interest income grew 129.5%, resulting in an earnings of $0.94 per diluted share, an increase of 118.6% over the prior fiscal year of $0.43.
Non-GAAP net income grew 54.2%, resulting in earnings of $1.19 per diluted share, an increase of 46.9% over the prior fiscal year of $0.81.
For the fourth quarter, revenue was $953.2 million, down 10.6% from the prior quarter. As Rob discussed, the hard disk drive shortage had more impact on our mainstream GPU segments than originally anticipated, and our Tegra 2 products declined more rapidly than expected. 
GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 51.4%, 0.8% lower than the prior quarter and our original expectations due to an additional charge in the quarter to settle a patent dispute.
Non-GAAP gross margin, which excluded discharge, was 52.5%, consistent with the record gross margin we achieved in Q3.
These results contributed to a GAAP net income of $116 million for the quarter or $0.19 per diluted share, and non-GAAP net income worth $158.1 million or $0.26 per diluted share.
Revenue results by business segment were as follows: Our GPU business was down 3.6% quarter on quarter due to the impact of the disk drive shortage on our mainstream GPU desktop and notebook businesses.
Our professional business was down 3.6% from the record level achieved in the third quarter. Our Consumer business was down 42.5% sequentially. As mentioned previously, this primarily related to the sharp decline in our Tegra 2 products ahead of the ramp of Tegra 3, as well as the seasonal decline in our game console revenue.
For GAAP, our outlook for the first quarter is as follows: Revenue at $900 million to $930 million; gross margin of 49.2%, plus or minus 1%; OpEx at $383 million; tax rate at approximately 20%.
For non-GAAP, we expect the following differences from our gap outlook: Gross margin of 49.5%, plus or minus 1%; and OpEx at $340 million.
Depreciation and amortization are expected in the range of $52 million to $56 million, and capital expenditures in the range of $35 million to $45 million. Diluted shares are expected to be 622.5 million.
As for the FY '13 outlook, our view of the market has changed and the outlook we gave in Q3 should no longer be relied upon. We are updating our FY '13 outlook as follows: We expect the overall PC market to experience continued headwind from the disk drive shortage. We expect our GPU business to gain share. Our Professional Solutions Business is expected to have another record year. Maximus enables us to sell more than 1 GPU until workstation, and new supercomputer centers around the world are anticipating the shipments of Kepler.
Tegra this year was $360 million, and we expect it to grow at least 50%. We expect gross margins to exit FY '13 at around 52%.
We expect our OpEx investments n FY '13 to be approximately $1.56 billion on a GAAP basis and $1.4 billion for non-GAAP. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We will now take questions.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wondering if you can give us a little bit more clarity on the outlook, in particular which segments do you see driving the reduction quarter-over-quarter? And why are you expecting the line in the gross margin? Is it really volume or is it mix or some o
componenttext: I wondering if you can give us a little bit more clarity on the outlook, in particular which segments do you see driving the reduction quarter-over-quarter? And why are you expecting the line in the gross margin? Is it really volume or is it mix or some other?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: The top line decline for Q1 is expected to be due to the hard disk drive shortage continuing, as well as a shortage of 28-nanometer wafer. We're ramping our Kepler generation very hard, and we could use more wafers. The gross margin decline is contributed
componenttext: The top line decline for Q1 is expected to be due to the hard disk drive shortage continuing, as well as a shortage of 28-nanometer wafer. We're ramping our Kepler generation very hard, and we could use more wafers. The gross margin decline is contributed almost entirely to the yields of 28-nanometer being lower than expected. And that is, I guess, unsurprising at this point. And because we have -- we use wafer-based pricing now, when the yield is lower, our cost is higher. And so we've transitioned to a wafer-based pricing for some time. And our expectation, of course, is that the yields will improve as they have in the previous generation and as the yields improve, our outlook would increase. And our cost will decline. And that's why we expect to exit the year at 52% or about.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're expecting to Tegra 3, as you know, Tegra 3 tablets are starting to ramp in the marketplace. But this quarter, we are expecting to announce and ship Tegra 3-based superphones. And the rumors of them are starting to an excitement about started to leak
componenttext: We're expecting to Tegra 3, as you know, Tegra 3 tablets are starting to ramp in the marketplace. But this quarter, we are expecting to announce and ship Tegra 3-based superphones. And the rumors of them are starting to an excitement about started to leak, but at Mobile World Congress is when we expect to announce these devices. And we expect to announce and ship them this quarter. And so we're expecting Q1 to be a sharp uptick in Tegra sales and shipments. Our expectation is Windows 8 is later in the year. And Microsoft has given their estimates about Windows 8, and our expectation is that there will be meaningful contributions from Windows 8 later in the year, starting probably in Q3.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. And just a follow up with respect to kind of what you're seeing in the PC market and specifically, the impact of hard drives. You may be give a little more color that. Obviously, we've heard from some of your competitors on that. It sounded lik
componenttext: All right. And just a follow up with respect to kind of what you're seeing in the PC market and specifically, the impact of hard drives. You may be give a little more color that. Obviously, we've heard from some of your competitors on that. It sounded like the hard drive availability is getting somewhat better depending on where you talk to. How do you see that playing out kind of over the next 2 quarters and so as it impacts your business?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, almost everybody has guided down. I think PC-centric semiconductor companies have guided down on average, I think, about 8% in Q1. And so I think everybody is expecting hard drive headwind to continue through Q1 and potentially through Q2. As far as
componenttext: Well, almost everybody has guided down. I think PC-centric semiconductor companies have guided down on average, I think, about 8% in Q1. And so I think everybody is expecting hard drive headwind to continue through Q1 and potentially through Q2. As far as what we see, Q4 started out with less shortage than we -- than people have predicted, and the reason for that was because there was a lot of channel inventory and people consumed the channel inventories. The channel inventory dried up. Prices of disk drive in the channels started to spiked. And as you know, channel business is a large part of the discrete GPU business. And China as a particularly large region for us, where a large amount of the PCs are built in channel, and their build where we call DIY. And so design-it-yourself or build it yourself or decided for you. And so we expect the parts and you go to on IT enabled the PC right there for you. So in those part of the regions where in countries, regions and countries where people build PCs like that, that's part price of disk drive price have decreased quite a bit. And so our sense is that, that's going to continue through Q1 and potentially through Q2.

componenttextpreview: We're -- we did about $316 million this year in Tegra 2 sales. We are expecting at least 50% growth year-over-year. The vast majority of that will be based on Tegra 3. ASPs of Tegra 3 is higher than Tegra 2, and our expectation is that it would stay that
componenttext: We're -- we did about $316 million this year in Tegra 2 sales. We are expecting at least 50% growth year-over-year. The vast majority of that will be based on Tegra 3. ASPs of Tegra 3 is higher than Tegra 2, and our expectation is that it would stay that way through the year.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Got it. And on the gross margin line, I think you guys, mentioned 49 on 5-year including 52. Where do you see the margin improvement coming? When do you see it coming?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our margin darg is almost nearly entirely related to 28-nanometer. And so the margin improvement will entirely from 28-nanometer. TSMC is doing fabulously with 28, and this year, with 28 relative to 40, is surely a huge improvement. But during transition
componenttext: Our margin darg is almost nearly entirely related to 28-nanometer. And so the margin improvement will entirely from 28-nanometer. TSMC is doing fabulously with 28, and this year, with 28 relative to 40, is surely a huge improvement. But during transition years, because we have so much of our business tied to the leading edge nodes and because when we transition GPUs, we transitioned so much of it at ounce. And this year, particularly unique this year is that the number of notebook design wins that we have and the number of 28-nanometer GPU design wins that we have is at OEMs much, much higher than our previous generation. And so all of the transition of 28 is going to be very fast. And so we're just going to have to continue to work with TSMC and get the yields of 28-nanometer up as fast as possible. And we surely expect that by the end of the year, we're going to be in a pretty good place. We're in a pretty decent place now, but we just need to get the yields up.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Cassidy with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Maybe along the lines of the 28-nanometer yield. Have you got categorized what the problem is? And is there a place? And also, just if you got all the product you need it, do you know what kind of gross margins would you come in?
componenttext: Maybe along the lines of the 28-nanometer yield. Have you got categorized what the problem is? And is there a place? And also, just if you got all the product you need it, do you know what kind of gross margins would you come in?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's no particular problem. This is the first major quarter of 28-nanometer shipments. There have been some shipments, there've been some shipments in previous quarters but very, very small. For TSMC, this is probably the first large quarter of shipmen
componenttext: There's no particular problem. This is the first major quarter of 28-nanometer shipments. There have been some shipments, there've been some shipments in previous quarters but very, very small. For TSMC, this is probably the first large quarter of shipments, and we're going to continue to improve yields from here. So there's nothing particularly long, this just early in the learning cycle of the new node. And so we'll improve it with every single else. And also, this isn't the problem that we can't solve. Everybody's using the same 28-nanometer. And so this affects all of us, anybody who uses 28-nanometer. So I think with everybody ramping production, this going to be a lot more learning cycle both from us and from other people. But TMSC is in a good place now and we just have to keep improving it.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: The professional solutions group has -- includes notebook workstations. And so whether it's HP workstations or mobile workstations or Dell mobile workstations or Fujitsu mobile workstations, Lenovo mobile workstations, Quadro is a standard n all of those workstations. So we're delighted when people go mobile because often times, they have a mobile workstation as well as desktop workstation. And so this is the good trend.

componenttext: In the Ivy Bridge generation, also lined up with the 28-nanometer GPU generation. And this is really toe-to-toe competition between the best GPUs in the marketplace. And our Kepler generation, which we hope to tell you more about soon, one design wins at virtually every single PC OEM in the world. And so this is probably the best GPU we've ever built, and the performance and power efficiency is surely the best that we've ever predicted. And as a result, our notebook penetration and notebook design win this year is expected to be very, very high.

componenttext: And so you're saying that we should expect to see those right away as Ivy Bridge comes out? componenttext: My guess is that and of course, this is just an estimate and at this point, but my guess is that we'll ship more in phones this year as we did last year in terms of units. And in terms of ASP's, it'll probably be close.

componenttextpreview: It will be seen through the year. And these yield improvement is a function of the number of cycles of learning. And now the cycles of learning, as we ramped up, TSMC, the cycle of the learning has really gone up. And so my expectation is that the overall
componenttext: It will be seen through the year. And these yield improvement is a function of the number of cycles of learning. And now the cycles of learning, as we ramped up, TSMC, the cycle of the learning has really gone up. And so my expectation is that the overall improvement will steadily improve on through the year.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Brian stepping in for Hans. I just wanted to follow-up on this 28-nanometer. Just to be clear, this is specific to 28-nanometer for GPUs for videos? Or is this across the industry for TSMC?
componenttext: This is Brian stepping in for Hans. I just wanted to follow-up on this 28-nanometer. Just to be clear, this is specific to 28-nanometer for GPUs for videos? Or is this across the industry for TSMC?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think this is -- I guess, rest of the industry would have to speak for themselves. But my guess is that this is across the industry. This 28-nanometer is still early in its maturing. There aren't that many 28-nanometer products in the marketplace as of
componenttext: I think this is -- I guess, rest of the industry would have to speak for themselves. But my guess is that this is across the industry. This 28-nanometer is still early in its maturing. There aren't that many 28-nanometer products in the marketplace as of now, and the number of cycles of learning has not very significant and the amount of volume is surely not very significant. At this point, we're ramping very hard all of our 28-nanometer products. And the yield is much better than 40-nanometer when it first came up. But it's not as good as we had expected, in our previous projections. And so we're going to have to work hard with TSMC and support them and encourage them and wish them well and get the 28-nanometer yield up as fast as possible.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up. You indicated that you expect the tax rates to remain been stable going forward. How do they trend in the January quarter?
componenttext: And just a follow up. You indicated that you expect the tax rates to remain been stable going forward. How do they trend in the January quarter?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shawn Webster with Macquarie.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is -- I had a question about pricing going on this quarter and then maybe into the next Intel desktops, notebook GPU in particular?
componenttext: This is -- I had a question about pricing going on this quarter and then maybe into the next Intel desktops, notebook GPU in particular?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Pricing is expected to be stable and healthy this year. The amount of 28-nanometer capacity in the world is not enough. And so I think we're expecting 28-nanometer to be constrained through the entire year. New generations of smartphones, new generations
componenttext: Pricing is expected to be stable and healthy this year. The amount of 28-nanometer capacity in the world is not enough. And so I think we're expecting 28-nanometer to be constrained through the entire year. New generations of smartphones, new generations of GPUs are going to drive the demand for 28-nanometer capacity or drive the demand for 28-nanometer devices. And so I think you're going to find that this year is going to continue to be tight. We could use more 28-nanometer wafers, and TSMC's management team has worked very hard on supporting us with our demand and driving cycle times hard and trying to improve yield. And so all of that is going to improve throughout the year and very steadily throughout the year. And if previous generations have been indication, TSMC will improve their performance incredibly fast.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And also, if you talk about channel inventories going into this quarter, do you think this a lot of buildup maybe the low end because of the Asia issue and maybe channel inventory and Tegra as well?
componenttext: And also, if you talk about channel inventories going into this quarter, do you think this a lot of buildup maybe the low end because of the Asia issue and maybe channel inventory and Tegra as well?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Channel inventory is actually okay, and there's no -- the channel is being very cautious in loading up, as you can imagine, whether it's because of currency volatility in Europe or because of shortage of disk drives. Nobody in the channel is being too her
componenttext: Channel inventory is actually okay, and there's no -- the channel is being very cautious in loading up, as you can imagine, whether it's because of currency volatility in Europe or because of shortage of disk drives. Nobody in the channel is being too heroic with respect to loading up inventory. So I think you're going to find the channel inventories relatively lean across the board. And on the high-end, it's extremely short.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: With respect to the attach rates, as you talk about that being driven lower by the hard drive shortages, so the price in hard drives being compensated by finding materials shared someplace else. Can you talk about how the hard drive shortage mitigates and
componenttext: With respect to the attach rates, as you talk about that being driven lower by the hard drive shortages, so the price in hard drives being compensated by finding materials shared someplace else. Can you talk about how the hard drive shortage mitigates and those prices come back down whether you expect the attach rate to go back up?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the attach rate of GPUs is driven not by anything but consumer demand. And I think that there are fewer PCs sold in Q4 than there was -- than the industry had expected. The attach rate of those PCs that were sold were stable and relatively consisten
componenttext: Well, the attach rate of GPUs is driven not by anything but consumer demand. And I think that there are fewer PCs sold in Q4 than there was -- than the industry had expected. The attach rate of those PCs that were sold were stable and relatively consistent with our model. And so your premise is I don't think it's correct. And attach rates seems to be stable. The number of PCs sold has reduced. Some people think it's cannibalization from a smartphone and tablets and other devices, but disk drive played a role in that as well. And so when the disk drive supply resumes, my sense is that the consumers demand will return to what they were and GPU attach will remain stable.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Understand. And then as a follow-up. In terms of the OpEx, I think the $1.56 billion you guided to for the year implies a bit of an uptick as it move throughout the year. Can you talk about where the incremental spending is being allocated towards?
componenttext: Understand. And then as a follow-up. In terms of the OpEx, I think the $1.56 billion you guided to for the year implies a bit of an uptick as it move throughout the year. Can you talk about where the incremental spending is being allocated towards?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just one clarification, that's on a GAAP basis, the $1.56 billion. It's $1.4 billion on a non-GAAP.
componenttext: Just one clarification, that's on a GAAP basis, the $1.56 billion. It's $1.4 billion on a non-GAAP.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's unchanged from our previous guidance. And what we've told you guys before, the increase investment relative to last year on an absolute basis has to do with the fact that we're investing a lot more in mobile devices. This last year was a big year for
componenttext: It's unchanged from our previous guidance. And what we've told you guys before, the increase investment relative to last year on an absolute basis has to do with the fact that we're investing a lot more in mobile devices. This last year was a big year for us. It was a big year because GPUs grew quite significantly despite the shortage of disk drive and softness in the market towards the end of the year. But it was a particularly big year for us because this was the first year that we really engaged the mobile market and our mobile position really became established. At this time, this last year, no one thought that we would really be as successful in the mobile market as we ended up being. And so that I think that today, we have now 3 generations of Android operating systems and devices behind us. We have tens and tens of smartphones and tens of tablets. We have engagements with nearly every single Tier 1 OEM in the world on the mobile side, as well as on the computing side. And so I think that this was a pretty big year from that perspective. And because of that traction and because of that success we've seen, we think it's really make sense for us to double down on mobile computing and go after it in a big way. And so we're going to have a lot more products this year than last, and you're going to see that we're going to have tablet devices, as well as tablet processors, as well as integrated processors with modems. And so this is a business and that's of investment surely but it's a very big went market opportunity, as you know.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna with JMP Securities.

componenttext: I was wondering within the 50% growth you're expecting for Tegra, are you factoring in contribution from Windows 8? Or -- and if so, how big a contribution might that be?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then I was wondering, if you're going to be seeing Tegra 3 ramping in your July quarter, is the early ramp going to be enough to perhaps help the gross margin line given that it's not going to be, if I'm understanding correctly, on the 28-nanometer no
componenttext: And then I was wondering, if you're going to be seeing Tegra 3 ramping in your July quarter, is the early ramp going to be enough to perhaps help the gross margin line given that it's not going to be, if I'm understanding correctly, on the 28-nanometer node?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We are going to be ramping Tegra 3 -- we're ramping Tegra 3 now. And so this quarter, Tegra 3 will make a large contribution. We're expecting Tegra to be up quarter-to-quarter about 50% as well. So Tegra 3 is ramping significantly even into the April quar
componenttext: We are going to be ramping Tegra 3 -- we're ramping Tegra 3 now. And so this quarter, Tegra 3 will make a large contribution. We're expecting Tegra to be up quarter-to-quarter about 50% as well. So Tegra 3 is ramping significantly even into the April quarter. And you're right that the gross margins for Tegra 3 is better than our 28-nanometer gross margins in the first quarter. And hopefully, 28-nanometer yields will improve and by second and third quarter time frame, it will make a difference.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last one if I could on the GPU business, excluding the professionals set, you gave a mix of expecting down PC market because of the hard disk drive constraints both market share gains, any ballparking on the net of that? Do you expect on the rev
componenttext: Okay. And last one if I could on the GPU business, excluding the professionals set, you gave a mix of expecting down PC market because of the hard disk drive constraints both market share gains, any ballparking on the net of that? Do you expect on the revenue basis of the year to be down, flat, up? Can you say at this juncture?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our expectation is that on the net our discrete GPU business will be up. And in Q3 time frame, we were expecting using industry analyst models of PC industry growth of 4% to 5%. I think the -- our estimates now are much lower than that and so we assume so
componenttext: Our expectation is that on the net our discrete GPU business will be up. And in Q3 time frame, we were expecting using industry analyst models of PC industry growth of 4% to 5%. I think the -- our estimates now are much lower than that and so we assume something lower than that. So we'll see how it turns out in the final analysis, but we're assuming relatively no growth in the overall PC market but because were gaining share, because of continue to grow our professionals business, our discrete GPU business year-over-year will grow.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jen-Hsun, can you talk a little bit about the competitive dynamics you see as you go in and compete for Tegra 3 wins? I mean, we're hearing a lot of competition on pricing and a lot of a guerrilla tactics out there. Can you talk about what you're seeing?
componenttext: Jen-Hsun, can you talk a little bit about the competitive dynamics you see as you go in and compete for Tegra 3 wins? I mean, we're hearing a lot of competition on pricing and a lot of a guerrilla tactics out there. Can you talk about what you're seeing?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We haven't met so many guerrillas yet, but elephants maybe. We compete primarily today with Qualcomm. And the reason for that is because there are 3 major opportunities in the smartphone marketplace this year that are really exciting. In the United States
componenttext: We haven't met so many guerrillas yet, but elephants maybe. We compete primarily today with Qualcomm. And the reason for that is because there are 3 major opportunities in the smartphone marketplace this year that are really exciting. In the United States, of course, LTE is very important. Outside of the United States -- and they have a very -- they have the only real integrated solution today and, in fact, they have the only shipping solution today and so they have a very good position on LTE than us. Outside the United States, we are LTE adoption is much further behind. The next major upgrade is quad core. Today's dual core phones used to be upgraded and so the next major upgrade, the next major superphone, the next major big thing is quad core. And so Tegra 3 is incredibly well positioned there. Sulci the United States, in Europe particularly, in China, you're going to see quad core Tegra 3 phones coming on throughout the year. The third growth opportunity is the 999 what some people call 1000 RMB phone. And this is an affordable, very affordable smartphone with dual core capability and the way that they describe it, the way the marketplace internalize it is it's a phone that has the capability of an iPhone but it's extremely affordable. That's a great opportunity for us because of Tegra 2 is a fabulous dual core and with a 3G modem, you could achieve 1000 RMB in China in the near future. And so that's a pretty exciting opportunity for us, and we're just about and to enter into that market opportunity. And so those are the kind of the market opportunities and the competitive dynamics. It's really primarily the 2 of us. I think the highest level the reason for that to do in order to be successful in the leading edge in that Tier 1 phones, you need to have a great application processor and a great application growth map. You need to have a world-class software stack because the software part of these phones have become the most complicated part. And the third, going forward is the ability to integrate a modem. And we were fortunate to have purchased Icera last year and our integrated well pretty exciting.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. So it sounds like your quad core features are compelling enough that pricing you're able to maintain industry pricing with your customers?
componenttext: Got it. So it sounds like your quad core features are compelling enough that pricing you're able to maintain industry pricing with your customers?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Yes, we're able to get better pricing on our Tegra 3.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya with Bank of America.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jen-Hsun, I wanted to address in this competitive issue from a different angle, which is from the handset vendor side. So increasingly, Apple and Samsung are taking more share in the market versus HTC, Motorola and others. So even though Tegra 3 could be
componenttext: Jen-Hsun, I wanted to address in this competitive issue from a different angle, which is from the handset vendor side. So increasingly, Apple and Samsung are taking more share in the market versus HTC, Motorola and others. So even though Tegra 3 could be a great product, how are new ensuring that during the you're engaging with the right set of customers? And what real underlying drivers that are going into this expectation of 50% growth for this year?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're expecting to grow at least 50% this year, and that comes from 3 different -- maybe 4 different sources, let me break it down. One is Tegra 3 phones. One is Tegra 2 phones for the 1000 RMB 1000 market, which is the fastest-growing segment in smartpho
componenttext: We're expecting to grow at least 50% this year, and that comes from 3 different -- maybe 4 different sources, let me break it down. One is Tegra 3 phones. One is Tegra 2 phones for the 1000 RMB 1000 market, which is the fastest-growing segment in smartphones today. The third is Android tablets. And as you know, we finally were able to put together a tablet that is both exciting, as well -- table architecture that's both exciting with Tegra 3 and Ice Cream Sandwich, as well as affordable. We've been able to reach the $249 price level for retail. And the fourth is Windows 8 on ARM. And so these 4 growth drivers, frankly, just last year, the only thing that really worked super well for us in even on Tegra 2 was smartphones, and that contributed to $360 million in revenues. And so this year, we're expecting smartphones from Tegra 3, from Tegra 2, from Tegra 3 Ice Cream Sandwich tablets and as well as Tegra 3 Windows on ARM tablets. And so there's a lot more opportunities for us. But you're right that Samsung and Apple are very, very strong. And so our strategy is actually very simple by teaming up with the best partners in the world, we would like to bring great technology to them and partner with them to build exquisite devices. And also to move faster. I mean, we as an industry has to move a lot faster inventory competitor position to marketplace more rapidly. And so by partnering with HTC and they are fantastic company, I'm not suggesting we announced this year but surely, a partner like HTC would be fabulous for NVIDIA to partner with.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I could just perhaps push back on some of those service. So for instance, the 1000 RMB market, there we have seen integration with connectivity being attractive features so how do you just that We have been features, so how do you address t
componenttext: Got it. And if I could just perhaps push back on some of those service. So for instance, the 1000 RMB market, there we have seen integration with connectivity being attractive features so how do you just that We have been features, so how do you address that? And then on Android tablets, you have some things are getting but outside of the Kindle Fire, we have not seen sales pickup as much or perhaps that's just my perception of the market. So if you could address those 2 issues also.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the 1000 RMB market has a lot of segments underneath that. And at 1000 RMB, you really need to have world-class phone. And right now there is a just a very good solution for world-class, high-performance dual core processor with integrated 3G modem.
componenttext: Well, the 1000 RMB market has a lot of segments underneath that. And at 1000 RMB, you really need to have world-class phone. And right now there is a just a very good solution for world-class, high-performance dual core processor with integrated 3G modem. And surely, there's 500 RMB phones and they have low-end integrated solutions with 3G. But nothing sufficiently good at the 1000 RMB to be able to claim that it's as good as an iPhone 4 but at a much affordable price. So that segment where you need to have a world-class high-performance dual core processor like Tegra 2 and a great software stack, along with 3G modems, as you know, quite affordable and quite abundant and they've been around for many years, integrating those together on build materials not too difficult. And so that's one. With respect to the tablets, Amazon Fire is really interesting product and it's great e-reader. But our belief is that there's the marketplace for tablets that are much more general-purpose. I think Asus Transformer Prime is a first example of a tablet that can really demonstrate differentiation, and people love it, and it's frankly my favorite computer now. And it's a lot of other people's favorite computers. It's a tablet sometimes. It's a full Notebook PC sometimes and a performance is really terrific. So I think this Ice Cream Sandwich addressed a lot of the challenge that the tablet industry has Android had last year with. But now with Ice Cream Sandwich, your phone is Ice Cream Sandwich, your tablet is Ice Cream Sandwich, all the application come off at the marketplace can work on both and so I think that unification is that only system allows that today answer, that I think is a great advance for the tablet market. And then lastly, at $249, if we can bring a quad core, if we can bring Tegra 3 to $249, and for those people who have seen and touched it, that tablet is going to sell like hot cakes, we believe, because it's the right price point, it's completely general-purpose and it's state-of-the-art. So we have reasons to believe that this tablet market is far from over, and there's a lot of interesting opportunities differentiation for this market.

componenttext: Two questions. The first one maybe sometime purgation for you, Jen-Hsun. Hard drive ASPs squeezing up GPUs for the build materials and then a shortage of capacity from 28-nanometer. Can you just give us a sense maybe rankles in terms of what's most impactful to sales?

componenttext: 28-nanometer shortage. I could use more 28-nanometer wafers today.

componenttext: About the same. I mean, I haven't thought of it that way but it's about the same. But from a gross margin perspective, obviously, much more from 28-nanometer. Those are problems that are going to get sold for the whole industry. I think as the industry as TSMC ramps more and more 28 nanometers, their capacity would increase and their yields would increase and their will reduce. This is a world-class company. Morris and the management team are all over it, and they're doing everything in their power, and history is any indication and it tends to be. They're going to work their way into our fabulous note here any time. And so we have just started ramping in the last several months. And so the Q1 is kind of a bit of a transition quarter for us. But I'm very confident that turn we're to 28-nanometer yield issues.

componenttext: Okay. And as a follow up, I heard you when you say at least 50% growth in Tegra. But your guidance there is nonetheless substantially lower than what your original guidance was. componenttextpreview: There one major delta. I'm glad you asked. there's one major delta from our previous guidance. About, I would say, a couple of quarters ago, I would've thought that unbalanced that Samsung was one of our largest customers as they were last year. But looki
componenttext: There one major delta. I'm glad you asked. there's one major delta from our previous guidance. About, I would say, a couple of quarters ago, I would've thought that unbalanced that Samsung was one of our largest customers as they were last year. But looking forward, my sense is on balance. Samsung will use their own application processors. They'll dabble outside probably and they'll use outside application processors like ours. We're never their own can serve their needs. But unbalanced they're going to try to use their own. And so that's the big delta that I've taken off of my guidance.

componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow up, can you update us on the CFO search? And can you also update us on Icera? You talked about it briefly with a roadmap, we might we expect any integrated product and also, do you expect to ship the expense of the phones in calendar '12?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are doing a CFO search. We have many interested candidates. I haven't decided on one yet and the reason for that this because I think Karen and the financial team are doing a fabulous job and have it allows me to be very choosy and instead of a v
componenttext: Sure. We are doing a CFO search. We have many interested candidates. I haven't decided on one yet and the reason for that this because I think Karen and the financial team are doing a fabulous job and have it allows me to be very choosy and instead of a very, very high bar. And so if you do know someone, absolutely call new but we have about a very is interested candidates. Icera. Icera is going to prove to be one of the smartest and one of the acquisitions in our history. We will have shipping modems this year for sure. And hopefully, sooner than later. And then our plan is to integrate our application processor, which as you know, is already one of best in the world, and the Icera modem into an integrated product for mainstream LTU market. And so we're doing that as quickly as can. And that's 1 of the reasons why we're investing heavily in OpEx is so that we could do this class of products for a much larger marketplace and much larger market opportunity for us.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is calling in for Raj Seth. A couple of quick ones. Firstly, given that your Tegra business had some scale now, how are you thinking about margins in that business, going forward? And secondly, what is the key growth opportunities affectional service
componenttext: This is calling in for Raj Seth. A couple of quick ones. Firstly, given that your Tegra business had some scale now, how are you thinking about margins in that business, going forward? And secondly, what is the key growth opportunities affectional services workstation business in 2012? And this 10% to 15% are still the right range to think about annual growth for that business?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let's see. The first question with respect to Tegra, we expect our gross margins to be in the range of the corporate average. And our estimates are that would be around that array of plus or minus, okay. Nothing dramatically different. Second is growth op
componenttext: Let's see. The first question with respect to Tegra, we expect our gross margins to be in the range of the corporate average. And our estimates are that would be around that array of plus or minus, okay. Nothing dramatically different. Second is growth opportunities for PSG. In the area of workstations, we introduced a concept called Maximus, a new concept technology called Maximus. It allows for the workstation to not only visualize but that also allows it to compute. So you could do simultaneous simulation of fluid dynamics while seeing the fluid flow over a structure like a car or motorcycles or whatever in realtime. And so Maximus has been received fantastically, and our hope is that more and more workstations will have not just one GPU inside for visualization but 1 GPUs. 1 for visualization and 1 for simulation. Next year, this year is also the year of Kepler. It's been 2.5 years since firming. And supercomputers and supercomputing centers around the world are waiting anxiously for Kepler to launch so that they can upgrade their supercomputers. So that's a growth opportunity for us. In the area of High Performance Computing as well, we're hoping that the work that we've done to make Tesla much easier to program for, it's called open ACC. It's a technique called directives, making it super easy for software programmers to take advantage of GPU computing and we worked with industry on that, as an open standard. So we're excited about the development of that. The response has been fabulous. And hopefully, that making GPUs easier to program will also increase its adoption. So those are some of the growth opportunity initiatives that we have going in. And our expectation is that the Quadro and Tesla in combination would PSG, will be a record year again this year.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Tamara, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Rob C
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Tamara, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the NVIDIA Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to your host, Rob Csongor, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call on annual and fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 results. With me on the call today from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Karen Burns, Interim Chief Finan
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to NVIDIA's conference call on annual and fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 results. 
With me on the call today from NVIDIA are Jen-Hsun Huang, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Karen Burns, Interim Chief Financial Officer. After our prepared remarks, we will open up the call to a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] .
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's call is being webcast live on NVIDIA's Investor Relations website and is also being recorded. A replay of the conference call will be available via telephone until February 22, 2012, and the webcast will be available for replay until our conference call to discuss our financial results for our first quarter of fiscal 2013. The content of today's conference call is NVIDIA's property and cannot be reproduced or transcribed without our prior written consent.
During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially. For a discussion of factors that could affect our future financial results and business, please refer to the disclosure in today's earnings release, our Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended October 30, 2011, and the reports we may file from time to time on Form 8-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
All our statements are made as of today, February 15, 2012, based on information available to us as of today, and except as required by law, we assume no obligation to update any such statements. Unless or otherwise noted, all references to market research and market share numbers throughout the call come from Mercury Research or Jon Peddie Research.
During this call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures. You can find a reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures in our financial release, which is posted on our website or in the case of our fiscal year 2013 outlook, the reconciliation is posted on our Investor Relations website.
With that, let's begin. After 5 consecutive quarters of sequential revenue growth, fourth quarter revenue was negatively impacted by the global disk drive shortage, caused by the flooding in Thailand, which upset the mainstream and GPU segment more than anticipated. 
Shipments by some PC OEMs were reduced, and higher disk drive prices constrained the ability of some PC OEMs to include a GPU in their systems.
Additionally, the Tegra 2 mobile business declined more rapidly than expected ahead of devices based on the Tegra 3 processor ramping into production in the first quarter of calendar year 2012. 
However, despite tough economic conditions and the exiting of our chipset business, NVIDIA recorded very good results for our full fiscal year 2012.
First, our overall business grew 33%, excluding the chipset business we've been exiting. Discrete GPUs, including GeForce, Quadro and Tesla grew sharply over the year. GPU attach rates remained strong at 53% of consumer PCs and 36% overall, according to Mercury Research data.
A research in PC gaming market saw games like Battlefield 3 and Modern Warfare 3 record over $1  billion in sales in their first week on the shelves. At the time of the launch of Battlefield 3, over 80% of gamers were below the recommended hardware specification to play the game, driving a significant increase in gamer GPU revenues over the year.
Our Professional Solutions Business had a record revenue year driven by large adoption of the Fermi generation of Quadro workstation products, as well as growth in emerging design economies such as India and China.
Our Tesla products were selected to power the world's fastest supercomputers, including Oak Ridge National Laboratory's upcoming Titan supercomputer. In addition, we made major strides in speeding up GPU computing applications support and code porting through our open HPC and directive initiatives.
And then one of our most important achievements for the year, we established a position in the mobile market. Tegra products captured share in Tier 1 tablets and smartphones. Over the course of the year, Tegra products shipped in 14 phones, 34 tablets in 18 of the top 20 carriers. We designed and shipped 3 generations of Android devices.
With Tegra 2, we were the first to ship dual-core mobile processors. And now with Tegra 3, we are the first to ship quad-core processors. The Tegra mobile processor has grown into a multi-hundred million dollar business.
Looking ahead, while we anticipate continued negative effects from the hard drive shortage, we believe gaming demand will continue to be robust, driven by the combination of our next-generation Kepler architecture and new hit games, such as Mass Effect 3 and Diablo III, both highly anticipated PC games coming in early calendar year 2012.
We believe that tax rates will continue to be stable, and that we are well positioned to grow notebook share with significant new notebook wins in the upcoming Ivy Bridge design cycle.
We are excited about a number of recent announcements we made in the professional space, which we believe will transform the workstation. 
First, yesterday, we announced that NVIDIA has joined forces with HP to introduce the world's first of all-in-one workstation, the Quadro-based HP Z1 Workstation. The Z1 features a 27-inch display that snaps open like the hood of the car, so users can easily swap out parts and make upgrades without any tools required.
This is the first and an entirely new category of professional workstation that we believe will tap market segments where space is a premium and users are unwilling to compromise performance. 
Second, we announced Maximus, a breakthrough for the workstation industry. Maximus enables for the first time a single workstation to simultaneously handle realtime visualization and compute-intensive simulation, functions which previously required separate steps or separate systems. 
Design and creative professionals have longed for machine that could perform these functions simultaneously. Maximus includes a combination of the Quadro and Tesla, unifying software technology and a rigorous certification process for professional applications. We believe Maximus will redefine the workflow in several segments and that workstations will increasingly shift with multiple GPUs.
Meanwhile, Tesla continued to make headlines in computational science. In addition to a number of new supercomputer deployment announcements, we announced breakthroughs in research. Two of the most important supercomputers in the world were recently announced in Oak Ridge National Labs' Titan and the NCSA's Blue Waters, both Tesla-based. Chinese researchers announced they had achieved a major breakthrough in the race to battle influenza by using NVIDIA Tesla GPUs to create the world's first computer simulation of a whole H1N1 influenza virus at the atomic level.
With Tegra 3, we believe our mobile business is poised for renewed growth. 
In addition to the launch of the world's first quad-core tablet, the ASUS Transformer Prime, we announced tablets based on Tegra 3 from a number of key OEMs, including Lenovo, ZTE, Fujitsu and Acer.
We also announced, together with ASUS, the world's first quad-core tablet priced at $249, the ASUS 7-inch MeMO ME370T. 
Next up, our Tegra 3 phones. We're looking forward to announcing some of the first ones at Mobile World Congress. 
With innovating, exciting new tablets at the high end, quad-core tablets at lowered price points for consumers, the world's first quad-core smartphones coming soon and Windows 8 devices later in the year, we remain confident that Tegra 3 will drive a new phase of growth for our mobile business.
With that, let me hand the call over to Karen.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. For the fiscal year 2012, revenue was $4 billion, up 12.8% from the prior year. GAAP net interest -- net income grew 129.5%, resulting in earnings of $0.94 per diluted share, an increase of 118.6% over the prior fiscal year of $0.43.Non-GAA
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. For the fiscal year 2012, revenue was $4 billion, up 12.8% from the prior year. GAAP net interest -- net income grew 129.5%, resulting in earnings of $0.94 per diluted share, an increase of 118.6% over the prior fiscal year of $0.43.
Non-GAAP net income grew 54.2%, resulting in earnings of $1.19 per diluted share, an increase of 46.9% over the prior fiscal year of $0.81.
For the fourth quarter, revenue was $953.2 million, down 10.6% from the prior quarter. As Rob discussed, the hard disk drive shortage had more impact on our mainstream GPU segments than originally anticipated, and our Tegra 2 products declined more rapidly than expected. 
GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 51.4%, 0.8% lower than the prior quarter and our original expectations due to an additional charge in the quarter to settle a patent dispute with Rambus.
Non-GAAP gross margin, which excluded this charge, was 52.5%, consistent with the record gross margins we achieved in Q3.
These results contributed to a GAAP net income of $116 million for the quarter or $0.19 per diluted share, and non-GAAP net income worth $158.1 million or $0.26 per diluted share.
Revenue results by business segment were as follows: Our GPU business was down 3.6% quarter on quarter, due to the impact of the disk drive shortage on our mainstream GPU desktop and notebook businesses.
Our professional business was down 3.6% from the record level achieved in the third quarter. Our Consumer business was down 42.5% sequentially. As mentioned previously, this primarily related to the sharp decline in our Tegra 2 products ahead of the ramp of Tegra 3, as well as the seasonal decline in our game console revenue.
For GAAP, our outlook for the first quarter is as follows: Revenue at $900 million to $930 million; gross margin of 49.2%, plus or minus 1%; OpEx at $383 million; and a tax at approximately 20%.
For non-GAAP, we expect the following differences from our gap outlook: Gross margin of 49.5%, plus or minus 1%; and OpEx at $340 million.
Depreciation and amortization are expected in the range of $52 million to $56 million, and capital expenditures in the range of $35 million to $45 million. Diluted shares are expected to be 622.5 million.
As for the FY '13 outlook, our view of the market has changed and the outlook we gave in Q3 should no longer be relied upon. We are updating our FY '13 outlook as follows: We expect the overall PC market to experience continued headwind from the disk drive shortage. We expect our GPU business to gain share. Our Professional Solutions Business is expected to have another record year. Maximus enables us to sell more than 1 GPU on to a workstation, and new supercomputer centers around the world are anticipating the shipments of Kepler.
Tegra this year was $360 million, and we expect it to grow at least 50%. We expect gross margins to exit FY '13 at around 52%.
We expect our OpEx investments in FY '13 to be approximately $1.56 billion on a GAAP basis and $1.4 billion for non-GAAP. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We will now take questions.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of JoAnne Feeney.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of JoAnne Feeney.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wondering if you can give us a little bit more clarity on the outlook, in particular which segments do you see driving the reduction quarter-over-quarter? And why are you expecting the decline in the gross margin? Is it purely volume or is it mix or som
componenttext: I wondering if you can give us a little bit more clarity on the outlook, in particular which segments do you see driving the reduction quarter-over-quarter? And why are you expecting the decline in the gross margin? Is it purely volume or is it mix or some of both?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: The top line decline for Q1 is expected to be due to the hard disk drive shortage continuing, as well as a shortage of 28-nanometer wafers. We're ramping our Kepler generation very hard, and we could use more wafers. The gross margin decline is contribute
componenttext: The top line decline for Q1 is expected to be due to the hard disk drive shortage continuing, as well as a shortage of 28-nanometer wafers. We're ramping our Kepler generation very hard, and we could use more wafers. The gross margin decline is contributed almost entirely to the yields of 28-nanometer being lower than expected. And that is, I guess, unsurprising at this point. And because we have -- we use wafer-based pricing now, when the yield is lower, our cost is higher. And so we've transitioned to a wafer-based pricing for some time. And our expectation, of course, is that the yields will improve as they have, and the previous generation knows, and as the yields improve, our output would increase. And our costs will decline. And that's why we expect to exit the year at 52% or about.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chris Caso with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Caso with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: With regard to the Tegra business and you gave some outlook for fiscal '13 in general, could you give us some indication as to how that looks as you go through the year? When do the Tegra 3 wins come up? And then perhaps talk about do the impact of Windows on ARM and you talked about that having some potential impact later this year, if you could expand on that.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're expecting to -- Tegra 3, as you know, Tegra 3 tablets are starting to ramp in the marketplace. But this quarter, we are expecting to announce and ship Tegra 3-based superphones. And they -- rumors of them are starting to -- and excitement about it i
componenttext: We're expecting to -- Tegra 3, as you know, Tegra 3 tablets are starting to ramp in the marketplace. But this quarter, we are expecting to announce and ship Tegra 3-based superphones. And they -- rumors of them are starting to -- and excitement about it is starting to leak, but at Mobile World Congress is when we expect to announce these devices. And we expect to announce and ship them this quarter. And so we're expecting Q1 to be a sharp uptick in Tegra sales and shipments. Our expectation is Windows 8 is later in the year. And Microsoft has given their estimates about Windows 8, and our expectation is that there will be meaningful contributions from Windows 8 later in the year, starting probably in Q3.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. And just as a follow-up, with respect to kind of what you're seeing in the PC market and specifically, the impact of hard drives. Maybe give a little more color that. Obviously, we've heard from some of your competitors on that and it sounded l
componenttext: All right. And just as a follow-up, with respect to kind of what you're seeing in the PC market and specifically, the impact of hard drives. Maybe give a little more color that. Obviously, we've heard from some of your competitors on that and it sounded like the hard drive availability is getting somewhat better depending on who you talk to. How do you see that playing out kind of over the next 2 quarters or so as it impacts your business?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, almost everybody has guided down. I think PC-centric semiconductor companies have guided down on average, I think, about 8% to Q1. And so I think everybody is expecting hard drive headwind to continue through Q1 and, potentially, through Q2. As far
componenttext: Well, almost everybody has guided down. I think PC-centric semiconductor companies have guided down on average, I think, about 8% to Q1. And so I think everybody is expecting hard drive headwind to continue through Q1 and, potentially, through Q2. As far as what we see, Q4 started out with less shortage than we -- than people have predicted, and the reason for that was because there was a lot of channel inventory and people consumed the channel inventories. The channel inventory dried up. Prices of disk drive in the channels started to spike. And, as you know, channel business is a large part of the discrete GPU business. And China is particularly a large, large region for us, where a large amount of the PCs are built in channel, and they are built -- what we call DIY. And so design it yourself or build it yourself or design it for you. And so you spec the parts and you go to on IT mall and they build a PC right there for you. And so in those part of the regions where -- in countries, regions and countries where people build PCs like that, the spot price of disk drives have increased quite a bit. And so our sense is that, that's going to continue through Q1 and potentially through Q2.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vijay Rakesh with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vijay Rakesh with Sterne Agee.

componenttext: I was just wondering on the F'13 guide, what is your guide for Tegra? And also, I mean, look at Tegra 3, what is the ASP -- what are the ballpark ASPs for Tegra 3 versus Tegra 2?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're -- we did about $360 million this year in Tegra 2 sales. We're expecting at least 50% growth year-over-year. The vast majority of that will be based on Tegra 3. ASPs of Tegra 3 is higher than Tegra 2, and our expectation is that it would stay that w
componenttext: We're -- we did about $360 million this year in Tegra 2 sales. We're expecting at least 50% growth year-over-year. The vast majority of that will be based on Tegra 3. ASPs of Tegra 3 is higher than Tegra 2, and our expectation is that it would stay that way through the year.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And on the gross margin line, I think you guys mentioned 49% here, 49% on 5 year exiting at 52%. Where do you see the margin improvement coming? When do you see it coming?
componenttext: Got it. And on the gross margin line, I think you guys mentioned 49% here, 49% on 5 year exiting at 52%. Where do you see the margin improvement coming? When do you see it coming?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our margin drag is almost nearly entirely related to 28-nanometer. And so the margin improvement will come entirely from 28-nanometer. And TSMC is doing fabulously with 28, and this year, with 28 relative to 40, is surely a huge improvement. But during tr
componenttext: Our margin drag is almost nearly entirely related to 28-nanometer. And so the margin improvement will come entirely from 28-nanometer. And TSMC is doing fabulously with 28, and this year, with 28 relative to 40, is surely a huge improvement. But during transition years, because we have so much of our business tied to the leading edge notes and because when we transition GPUs, we transitioned so much of it at once. And this year, particularly unique this year is that the number of notebook design wins that we have and the number of 28-nanometer GPU design wins that we have is at OEMs is much, much higher than our previous generation. And so all of the transition of 28 is going to be very fast. And so we're just going to have to continue to work with TSMC and get the yields of 28-nanometer up as fast as possible. And we surely expect that by the end of the year, we're going to be in a pretty good place. We're in a pretty decent place now, but we just need to get the yields up.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Cassidy with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Cassidy with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Maybe along the lines of the 28-nanometer yield. Have you got categorized what the problem is, and is there a place? And also, I just -- if you got all the product you needed, do you know what kind of gross margins would you have come in?
componenttext: Maybe along the lines of the 28-nanometer yield. Have you got categorized what the problem is, and is there a place? And also, I just -- if you got all the product you needed, do you know what kind of gross margins would you have come in?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's no particular problem. This is the first major quarter of 28-nanometer shipments. There have been some shipments, there've been some shipments in previous quarters but very, very small. And so for TSMC, this is probably the first large quarter of
componenttext: There's no particular problem. This is the first major quarter of 28-nanometer shipments. There have been some shipments, there've been some shipments in previous quarters but very, very small. And so for TSMC, this is probably the first large quarter of shipments, and we're going to continue to improve yields from here. So there's nothing particularly wrong, this is just early in the learning cycle of the new node. And so we'll improve it with every single outs. And also, this isn't a problem that we can solve. Everybody's using the same 28-nanometer. And so this affects all of us, anybody who uses 28-nanometer. So I think with everybody ramping production, there's going to be a lot more learning cycles both from us and from other people. But TMSC is in a good place now and we just have to keep improving it.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just as follow-up over. On the professional services group, can you say that the trend towards mobile workstations is? And how does that affect your revenues for 2013?
componenttext: And just as follow-up over. On the professional services group, can you say that the trend towards mobile workstations is? And how does that affect your revenues for 2013?

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: The Professional Solutions group has -- includes notebook workstations. And so whether it's HP workstations or mobile workstations or Dell mobile workstations or Fujitsu mobile workstations, Lenovo mobile workstations, Quadro is a standard in all of those
componenttext: The Professional Solutions group has -- includes notebook workstations. And so whether it's HP workstations or mobile workstations or Dell mobile workstations or Fujitsu mobile workstations, Lenovo mobile workstations, Quadro is a standard in all of those workstations. So we're delighted when people go mobile because often times, they have a mobile workstation as well as a desktop workstation. And so this is a good trend.

headline: NVIDIA Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Ellis with Caris & Company.
